words.def: a microprocessor, ASIC or expansion card designed to offload a specific task from the CPU, often containing fixed function hardware; a common example is a Graphics processing unit.
words.name: accelerator

words.def: a register in a CPU in which intermediate arithmetic and logic results are stored.
words.name: accumulator

words.def: the unique integer number that specifies a memory location in an address space
words.name: address

words.def: a mapping of logical addresses into physical memory or other memory mapped devices.
words.name: address space

words.def: an accelerator aimed running artificial neural networks or other machine learning and machine vision algorithms (either training or deployment), e.g. Movidius Myriad 2, TrueNorth, Tensor processing unit etc.
words.name: AI accelerator

words.def: Advanced Technology extended - a motherboard form factor specification developed by Intel in 1995 to improve on previous DE factor standards like the AT form factor.
words.name: ATX

words.def: The dimensions and layout (form factor) of the motherboard for the IBM AT.
words.name: AT

words.def: Accelerated Graphics Port - a high-speed point-to-point channel for attaching a video card to a computer's motherboard, primarily to assist in the acceleration of 3D computer graphics.
words.name: AGP

words.def: a subsystem that transfers data between computer components inside a computer or between computers.
words.name: bus

words.def: a optical disc storage medium designed to supersede the DVD format.
words.name: Blu-ray Disc

words.def: A small, fast local memory that transparently buffers access to a larger but slower or more distant/higher latency memory or storage device, organised into cache lines. Automatically translates accesses to the underlying resources address space to locations in the cache.
words.name: cache

words.def: A small block of memory within a cache; the granularity of allocation,refills,eviction; typically 32-128 bytes in size.
words.name: cache line

words.def: The process of keeping data in multiple caches synchronised in a multi-processor shared memory system, also required when DMA modifies the underlying memory.
words.name: cache coherency

words.def: freeing up data from within a cache to make room for new cache entries to be allocated; controlled by a cache replacement policy. Caused by a cache miss whilst a cache is already full.
words.name: cache eviction

words.def: finding data in a local cache, preventing the need to search for that resource in a more distant location (or to repeat a calculation).
words.name: cache hit

words.def: Not finding data in a local cache, requiring use of the cache policy to allocate and fill this data, and possibly performing evicting other data to make room.
words.name: cache miss

words.def: A pathological situation where access in a cache cause cyclical cache misses by evicting data that is needed in the near future.
words.name: cache thrashing

words.def: The number of potential cache lines in an associative cache that a specific physical addresses can be mapped to; higher values reduce potential collisions in allocation.
words.name: cache ways

words.def: Compact Disc-Recordable; a variation of the optical compact disc which may be written to once.
words.name: CD-R

words.def: Cache-only memory architecture, a multiprocessor memory architecture where an address space is dynamically shifted between processor nodes based on demand.
words.name: COMA

words.def: a variation of the optical compact disc which may be written to many times.
words.name: Compact Disc-ReWritable

words.def: (Compact Disc Read-Only Memory) - a pre-pressed optical compact disc which contains data or music playback.
words.name: CD-ROM

words.def: (or integrated circuit) - a miniaturised electronic circuit that has been manufactured in the surface of a thin substrate of semiconductor material.
words.name: chip

words.def: the memory that stores the microcode of a CPU.
words.name: control store

words.def: the portion of a CPU which actually performs arithemetic and logical operations. A CPU may have multiple cores (e.g. "a quad-core processor").
words.name: core

words.def: in modern usage, a synonym for main memory, dating back from the pre-semiconductor-chip times when the dominant main memory technology was magnetic core memory.
words.name: core memory

words.def: Central processing unit - the portion of a computer system that executes the instructions of a computer program.
words.name: CPU

words.def: Conventional Peripheral Component Interconnect - a computer bus for attaching hardware devices in a computer.
words.name: Conventional PCI

words.def: Computer chassis, cabinet, box, tower, enclosure, housing, system unit or simply case - the enclosure that contains most of the components of a computer (usually excluding the display, keyboard and mouse).
words.name: Computer case

words.def: The name used to denote the dimensions, power supply type, location of mounting holes, number of ports on the back panel, etc.
words.name: Computer form factor

words.def: (or chip set) - a group of integrated circuits, or chips, that are designed to work together. They are usually marketed as a single product.
words.name: Chipset

words.def: a generic term that refers to a high-performance input/output (I/O) architecture that is implemented in various forms on a number of computer architectures, especially on mainframe computers..
words.name: Channel I/O

words.def: a cache in a CPU or GPU servicing data load and store requests, mirroring main memory (or VRAM for a GPU).
words.name: D-cache

words.def: local memory associated with a hardware device such as an graphics processing unit or OpenCL compute device, distinct from main memory.
words.name: Device memory

words.def: (Direct Access Storage Device) A mainframe terminology introduced by IBM denoting secondary storage with random access, typically (arrays of) hard disk drives.
words.name: DASD

words.def: (dual in-line memory module);A series of dynamic random-access memory integrated circuits. These modules are mounted on a printed circuit board and designed for use in personal computers, workstations and servers.
words.name: DIMM

words.def: DisplayPort is a digital display interface developed by the Video Electronics Standards Association (VESA). The interface is primarily used to connect a video source to a display device such as a computer monitor, though it can also be used to transmit audio, USB, and other forms of data.
words.name: DisplayPort

words.def: a cache where each physical address may only be mapped to one cache line, indexed using the low bits of the address. Simple but highly prone to allocation conflicts.
words.name: Direct mapped cache

words.def: Direct memory access - the ability of a hardware device such as a disk drive or network interface to access main memory without intervention from the CPU, provided by one or more DMA channels in a system.
words.name: DMA

words.def: (Digital Video Disc or Digital Versatile Disc) - an optical compact disc - of the same dimensions as compact discs (CDs), but store more than six times as much data.
words.name: DVD

words.def: Digital Visual Interface (DVI) is a video display interface developed by the Digital Display Working Group (DDWG). The digital interface is used to connect a video source to a display device, such as a computer monitor.
words.name: DVI

words.def: (Dynamic random-access memory) - a type of random-access memory that stores each bit of data in a separate capacitor within an integrated circuit and which must be periodically refreshed to retain the stored data.
words.name: DRAM

words.def: refers to a superscalar pipeline capable of executing 2 instructions simultaneously.
words.name: dual issue

words.def: A hardware device or software to protect a computer from viruses, malware, trojans etc.
words.name: Firewall

words.def: fixed programs and data that internally control various electronic devices.
words.name: firmware

words.def: a data storage medium that is composed of a disk of thin, flexible ("floppy") magnetic storage medium encased in a square or rectangular plastic shell.
words.name: floppy disk

words.def: a device for reading floppy disks.
words.name: floppy disk drive

words.def: a type of non volatile computer storage chip that can be electrically erased and reprogrammed.
words.name: Flash Memory

words.def: a non-volatile storage device that stores data on rapidly rotating rigid (i.e. hard) platters with magnetic surfaces.
words.name: hard drive

words.def: the physical components of a computer.
words.name: hardware

words.def: (High-Definition Multimedia Interface) - a compact interface for transferring encrypted uncompressed digital audio and video data to a device such as a computer monitor, video projector or digital television.
words.name: HDMI

words.def: a memory architecture where program machine code and data are held in separate memories, more commonly seen in microcontrollers and digital signal processors.
words.name: Harvard architecture

words.def: any peripheral equipment used to provide data and control signals to an information processing system.
words.name: input device

words.def: the communication between an information processing system (such as a computer), and the outside world.
words.name: input/output

words.def: (Input/Output Operations Per Second, pronounced eye-ops) - a common performance measurement used to benchmark computer storage devices like hard disk drives.
words.name: IOPS

words.def: a group of several bits in a computer program that contains an operation code and usually one or more memory addresses.
words.name: instruction

words.def: a cache in a CPU or GPU servicing instruction fetch requests for program code (or shaders for a GPU), possibly implementing modified Harvard architecture if program machine code is stored in the same address space and physical memory as data.
words.name: I-cache

words.def: A stage in a pipeline that load the next instruction referred to by the program counter.
words.name: Instruction fetch

words.def: an input device, partially modeled after the typewriter keyboard, which uses an arrangement of buttons or keys, to act as mechanical levers or electronic switches.
words.name: keyboard

words.def: instructions used to transfer data between memory and processor registers.
words.name: Load/store instructions

words.def: An instruction set architecture where arithmetic/logic instructions may only be performed between processor registers, relying on separate load/store instructions for all data transfers.
words.name: Load-store architecture

words.def: memory associated closely with a processing element, e.g. a cache, scratchpad, the memory connected to one processor node in a NUMA or COMA system, or device memory (such as VRAM) in an accelerator
words.name: Local memory

words.def: powerful computer used mainly by large organizations for bulk data processing such as census, industry and consumer statistics, enterprise resource planning, and financial transaction processing.
words.name: mainframe

words.def: the largest random access memory in a memory hierarchy (before offline storage) in a computer system; i.e. distinct from caches or scratchpads; usually consists of DRAM.
words.name: main memory

words.def: the address of a location in a memory or other address space.
words.name: memory address

words.def: a memory architecture in a computer system, e.g. NUMA, uniform memory access, COMA, etc.
words.name: Computer memory architecture

words.def: The pattern with which software or some other system (a accelerator , or DMA channel) accesses memory, affecting locality of reference and parallelism.
words.name: memory access pattern

words.def: a variation of Harvard architecture used for most CPUs with separate non-coherent instruction and data caches (assuming that code is immutable), but still mirroring the same main memory address space, and possibly sharing higher levels of the same cache hierarchy
words.name: Modified Harvard architecture

words.def: the central printed circuit board (PCB) in many modern computers which holds many of the crucial components of the system, while providing connectors for other peripherals.
words.name: motherboard

words.def: devices that are used to store data or programs on a temporary or permanent basis for use in an electronic digital computer.
words.name: memory

words.def: an electronic visual display for computers.
words.name: monitor

words.def: a pointing device that functions by detecting two-dimensional motion relative to its supporting surface; motion is usually mapped to a cursor in screen space; typically used to control a graphical user interface on a desktop computer or for CAD etc.
words.name: mouse

words.def: small connectors used on some laptops and other systems in place of the standard VGA connector.
words.name: Mini-VGA

words.def: a layer of hardware-level instructions involved in the implementation of higher level machine code instructions in many computers and other processors.
words.name: Microcode

words.def: a type of read-only memory (ROM) whose contents are programmed by the integrated circuit manufacturer.
words.name: Mask ROM

words.def: a collection of computers and other devices connected by communications channels, e.g. by ethernet or wireless networking
words.name: network

words.def: Non-uniform memory access
words.name: NUMA

words.def: a computer network on a single semiconductor chip, connecting processing elements, fixed function units or even memories and caches. Increasingly common in System on a chip designs.
words.name: NOC

words.def: memory that can retain the stored data even when not powered.
words.name: Non-volatile memory

words.def: random-access memory that retains its data when power is turned off.
words.name: Non-volatile random-access memory

words.def: a disk drive that uses laser light or electromagnetic waves near the light spectrum as part of the process of reading or writing data to or from optical discs.
words.name: optical disc drive

words.def: the set of software that manages computer hardware resources and provide common services for computer programs, typically loaded by the BIOS on booting.
words.name: Operating system

words.def: Several bits in a computer program instruction that specify which operation to perform.
words.name: Operation code

words.def: another name for a USB flash drive.
words.name: pen drive

words.def: a device attached to a computer but not part of it.
words.name: peripheral

words.def: Any general-purpose computer whose size, capabilities, and original sales price make it useful for individuals, and which is intended to be operated directly by an end user, with no intervening computer operator.
words.name: personal computer

words.def: The pre-loading of instructions or data before needed either by dedicated cache control instructions or predictive hardware, to mitgate latency.
words.name: prefetching

words.def: A peripheral which produces a text or graphics of documents stored in electronic form, usually on physical print media such as paper or transparencies.
words.name: printer

words.def: refers to a level of semiconductor manufacturing technology, one of several successive transistor shrinks.
words.name: Process node

words.def: a processor in a multiprocessor system or cluster, connected by dedicated communication channels or a network.
words.name: Processor node

words.def: an electronic circuit (either a microprocessor or an internal component of one) that may function autonomously or under external control, performing arithmetic and logic operations on data, possibly containing local memory, and possibly connected to other processing elements via a network, network on a chip, or cache hierarchy.
words.name: Processing element

words.def: the process of pre-loading instructions or data into a cache ahead of time, either under manual control via prefetch instructions or automatically by a prefetch unit which may use runtime heuristics to predict the future memory access pattern.
words.name: Prefetch

words.def: Power supply unit - A unit of the computer that converts mains AC to low-voltage regulated DC for the power of all the computer components.
words.name: PSU

words.def: Programmable Read-Only Memory - a type of non-volatile memory chip that may be programmed after the device is constructed.
words.name: PROM

words.def: Peripheral Component Interconnect Express - a computer expansion bus standard designed to replace the older PCI, PCI-X, and AGP bus standards.
words.name: PCIe

words.def: PCI-eXtended - a computer bus and expansion card standard that enhances the 32-bit PCI Local Bus for higher bandwidth demanded by servers.
words.name: PCI-X

words.def: (Redundant Array of Independent Disks) - data storage schemes that can divide and replicate data across multiple hard disk drives in order to increase reliability, allow faster access, or both.
words.name: RAID

words.def: Random-access memory - any form of computer data storage that allow stored data to be accessed in any order (i.e., at random).
words.name: RAM

words.def: Read Only Memory - a type of memory chip that retains its data when its power supply is switched off.
words.name: ROM

words.def: a computer which may be used to provide services to clients.
words.name: server

words.def: computer programs and other kinds of information read and written by computers.
words.name: software

words.def: Single in-line memory module - a type of memory module containing random access memory used in computers from the early 1980s to the late 1990s.
words.name: SIMM

words.def: (or solid-state disk or electronic disk) a data storage device that uses integrated circuit assemblies as memory to store data persistently.
words.name: Solid-state drive

words.def: Static random-access memory - a type of semiconductor memory that uses bistable latching circuitry to store each bit. The term static differentiates it from DRAM which must be periodically refreshed.
words.name: SRAM

words.def: Synchronous dynamic random access memory - dynamic random access memory that is synchronized with the system bus.
words.name: SDRAM

words.def: A peripheral storage device that allows only sequential access, typically using magnetic tape.
words.name: tape drive

words.def: An electronic or electromechanical hardware device that is used for entering data into, and displaying data from, a computer or a computing system.
words.name: terminal

words.def: Also known as a touchpad; a pointing device consisting of specialized surface that can translate the motion and position of a user's fingers or a stylus to a relative position on a screen.
words.name: trackpad

words.def: a cache of decoded micro-operations in a CISC processor (e.g x86). [1]
words.name: uop cache

words.def: Universal Serial Bus - a specification to establish communication between devices and a host controller (usually a personal computers).
words.name: USB

words.def: A flash memory device integrated with a USB interface. USB flash drives are typically removable and rewritable.
words.name: USB flash drive

words.def: Video Graphics Array - the last graphical standard introduced by IBM to which the majority of PC clone manufacturers conformed.
words.name: VGA

words.def: memory that requires power to maintain the stored information.
words.name: Volatile memory

words.def: A video camera that feeds its images in real time to a computer or computer network, often via USB, Ethernet, or Wi-Fi.
words.name: Webcam

words.def: A cache where store operations are buffered in cache lines, only reaching main memory when the entire cache line is evicted
words.name: Write back cache

words.def: A cache where store operations are immediately written to the underlying main memory.
words.name: Write through cache

words.def: The set of data used by a processor during a certain time interval, which should ideally fit into a CPU cache for optimum performance.
words.name: Working set
